text: Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted sweet malt, dark chocolate, & vanilla; Flavor of roasted malt, caramel, coffee, dark bittersweet chocolate, and some anise/licorice; Nicely balanced; Pretty decent.

12 ounce bottle from Whole Foods Wauwatosa, 8/22/16. Near black with a large foamy brown head. Good retention. Aroma of nuts, chocolate, roast. The taste is chocolate, nuts, roast, caramel, cocoa. Medium bodied, low carbonation, well balanced. Delicious.

Big-tasting, full-bodied stout has just the slightest edge of hops to tamp down the major malts at work. Enjoyed on tap along side a Brie Burger at Ale Asylums Milwaukee Riverhouse -- great combination.

This is a pretty damn decent American stout--and not too sweet even though it mentions sweet malt on the label. Its dark w/ a thin head of fine bubbles. Its got a big roasty nose w/ maybe a bit of a savory hop undertone. This is big and creamy on the palate and just shy of being too much. Theres an interesting anise note and some cherry like fruitiness but also a slight but unfortunate ashy taste. This is pretty solid all around and drinks a lot bigger than its gravity would indicate. Fans of big stouts should definitely check this out.
Bottle. Black with tan head. Coffee malt aroma. It had an oily mouth feel and a balanced finish.

Bottle from Brunos via lake beer fridge....but consumed in Chicago. 

Pours almost black into a 22 oz snifter....nice taupe head that quickly fades...minimal lacing.

Nose is coffee...one of my favorites so Im kinda hooked right off. A little anise in the initial mouth...just a bit. Very tasty...coffee there as well.

Sweet...bit more coffee / anise....lingers too.

Very tasty...will do another...later.
Bottle shared by my friend John. Pours near black with a thick tan head and a strong treacle aroma. There is a hearty dark molasses flavor with hint of coffee and a smooth anise finish.
Bottle shared by john. Pours black with white head. Taste is roasted malts with lots of coffee

From notes. Enjoyed at the Great Taste of the Midwest on August 08. At this point, Im not going to lie, we were just trying to drink until they threw us out. The pour is a dark brown, near black, with a thick, lighter tan head and a couple pieces of lace. The aroma is full of roasted malt and chocolate with a bit of oat and some hints of coffee. I wish it were a little more aromatic, but its late, and I might be drunk. The flavors are a little better. The chocolate is a little bitter, the roasted malts work well, and there is even a little caramel on the back end. Im also getting some molasses mixed in there. The mouth feel is decently thick with a soft carbonation, but it does fall off of the tongue pretty quick. The aftertaste is lingeringly roasty with a little sweet molasses. Not bad.

Pours a dark brown almost black like oil with similar viscosity and nice khaki colored head. Roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, oats, and some light toffee on the nose; follows onto the palate. Full bodied stout here. Finishes with coffee and chocolate, slight roastiness as well.

Pours opaque chocolate brown with a very thick light tan head. Rich aroma has notes of roasted malt, quality coffee, charred wood, and semi-sweet chocolate. Flavor has pleasing notes of sweet roast malt, chocolate, quality coffee and molasses. Mouthfeel has firm, smooth body and some decent fizz. Slick and big - enjoy.

Look: pours a dark black. Light brown head. Slightly clear.
Smell: roasted malts. Cocoa powder. Coffee.
Taste: coffee. Roasted malts. 
Feel: thin mouth feel. Medium low carbonation. 
Overall: nice beer. Easy drinker. Very smooth.
First drank: home 3/17/15
Vintage: 2015

Deep dark brown with ample tan head that lasts and sticks. Smell is heavy sweet malts, cocoa, touch vanilla, hints of dark fruits. Taste is big chocolate (both milk and dark), vanilla, heavy sweet. Creamy, full body. Quite tasty.
Deep black pour with a mocha head. Aroma is roasted malt, dark fruit. Taste is roasted malt, dark fruit, creamy, coffee, very tasty. Great lacing, Chalky.

Bottle. Poured very dark, almost black, very little head. Aroma is inviting. Flavor begins with an edge and lots a tangy carbonation, but it smooths out with notes of chocolate, and mild coffee. A good stout, not too rich.

Bottle. Black coffee, licorice, wood ash, and chocolate malt aroma. Dark brown with moderate tan head. Sweet light licorice, coffee, dark chocolate malt, and moderately bitter dry hay flavor. Decent body. Very nice.

Very dark brown, very thin latte-colored head. Not tasting the coffee so much, this falls on the chocolate side of things. Pretty fair stout. Very smooth. Very little bitterness. Alcohol masked well. Maybe a little musty.

Aroma is dark dried fruit, dark chocolate. Color is dark, dark brown with a tiny tan head. Taste is juicy dark dried fruit, some tropical fruit sweetness, dark chocolate, a little bit of coffee, and lots of roasted grain with a little hops poking through. Palate is a bit light and dry. Good and solid, but not great.

pours black with a medium mahogany brown lacy head. Aroma is strong. Burnt toast, malt, coffee, and dark chocolate. Thick creamy mouth feel. Taste is rich, slightly bitter with coffee and dark chocolate notes.  Alcohol presence kind of noticeable.  Some lingering good bitterness on the finish. Good beer.

Pours black with a thinner, reddish brown head. This has an aroma thats a little sweet, with vanilla, chocolate, coffee, and toffee, with the vanilla standing out the most. The taste retains that mildly sweetness found in the nose. Its rich as advertised as well. There is a good mixture of coffee and vanilla. These are complimented with roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, and hints of plum. The aftertaste is coffee. Lighter in body, with a syrupy texture, and lacking much in carbonation. This one is tasty and goes down very easily. Recommended.

Poured from a bottle. Big foamy head. Aroma is full of chocolate and coffee. Flavor follows suit with a great blend of dark chocolate, coffee, maybe a hint of anise. Great mouthfeel throughout. Nice long, dry finish.

Bottle:
Pours black with a small brown head.
Chocolate, light coffee aroma.
Taste is mild coffee, roast, chocolate.
A bit of dark fruit...plum....
Slight coffee-ground bittering.
Dry finish, very mild-mannered and easy drinking.

Bottle. Pours black with very little head and lacing. Mild aroma of coffee and chocolate and some dark fruit. Taste is a little coffee and chocolate and plum or prune. Good but tastes more like a porter.

Excellent! Appearance is a thick velvety tan head that lasts forever; lots of lace and an opaque brown black color. Aroma at first is just dry dark roasted coffee and then the mall to comes on and I pick up more of vanilla and Cocoa and toffee. Flavor is like aroma; carbonic Tang is upfront but toned down there's a bit of sweetness but also tonedown; lovely beer. Body is perfect. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very malty aroma on this one. Chocolate, cocoa, coffee, earthy and a little bitter. Oily and a little licorice taste. 12oz bottle share pour at home.

Super black coffee start with a sweet black coffee finish. Had a bottle pour which is black wig a tan head. Had a kasers

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma is coffee, dry/dark malts and a hint of fruit/acidity. The flavor is coffee, chocolate, dark malts, fruit and a dryish/acidic finish.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2014 On tap at Ale Asylum. Pours black with a thick chocolate colored head. Aroma of dark chocolate, vanilla, toffee, roasted malt. Flavor of rich liquor-laden chocolate syrup, dark chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla. SO chocolatey! It is like dessert in a glass. Not the artificial tootsie roll chocolate either- rich dark chocolate and dark chocolate fudge. Heavenly.
7/4/9/4/16 (4.0/5)

Sample at the brewpub. Inky black color with a medium creamy tan head that dissipates steadily to a wispy film. Small patches of lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Medium bodied with a strong charred malt character and notes of coffee and cocoa. The finish is roasty with a coffee and malt aftertaste. Above average overall.
Draft. Black with thin brown head. Aroma of dark chocolate and coffee. Medium/heavy body, extra dark chocolate, coffee, and a chocolate finish.

On draft at the brewpub. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, cream, milky sweetness, roasted dark malts, touch of the oatmeal and a faint hint of yeast esters. Largely black in color with a lasting, creamy, fine, khaki head. Flavor profile is a touch sweet, more chocolate, coffee, roasted malts and some faint bubblegum/banana, very faint bitterness and dark breadiness appearing at the finish, some bittersweet aspects throughout. Smooth and fairly hefty in feel, body is full as well. A rather proper Oatmeal Stout, all in all.

7oz shorty on tap at the brewpub. Black color. Thin light brown head, leaves very good thicker lace. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, kind of crisp lighter carbonation. Kind of chewy texture. Light slick finish. Moderate bitter taste, moderate sweet, light hint of the alcohol. Some dark chocolate, mild coffee roast, light bit of dark fruit and a hint of metallic in the flavor. Alright bigger bodied oatmeal stout. Solid.

On-tap pours a dark brown color with a bubbly light brown head. The aroma is sweet with chocolate and hint of coffee. This taste like a big kids chocolate milk in the form of beer. Very interesting, I cant say Ive ever had anything quite like it.
Quite possibly the best stout Ive had. Not a lot of experience with stouts but the coffee flavor is smooth and subtle oatmeal taste. Yum

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2014 Very dark brown beer with tan head. Roasted malt and light coffee aroma and taste. Definitely a roasted beer, more roast than sweet taste. Creamy finish. Good stout, big roasted flavor that has a medium finish. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This beer turned me on to stouts (now a favorite style of mine), and Im happy to say that my opinion hasnt changed at all. Great aroma (Ive always detected a lot more coffee notes than Id expect for a beer brewed with 0 coffee). Very little light gets through the dark, dark brown brew. If I had one critique, it would be that the mouthfeel is a *tiny* bit thin now that Ive had a lot of other stouts.
On tap at brewpub. Pours black. Sweet medium body with toasty malts, chocolate, and coffee. Not bad.
Awesome stout on tap at the brewery, dark chocolate, delciousness all around
Draft. A slick and nicely roasty very light bodied and almost vhuggable like a guiness

On tap at the brewery. Solid. Moderately sweet. Just a good oatmeal stout. A bit sticky.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Had it on tap at Ale Asylum in Madison Wi. Poured black with a slight coffee aroma and an oatmeal coffee taste.
Pours coffee black with tan head. Aroma of deep chocolate and coffee with toffee notes. Taste is sweet with a bitter finish but overall amazing finish. Great stout!

Had this on tap at Stolps Stein Haus in La Crosse WI. Really nice stout had some interesting (I dont want to say licorice but I cant think of a better word) flavors that I thought were fairly unique to this beer.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2013 Tasted on tap at Ale Asylum. Dark brown to black in color. Slight coffee aroma, bold taste, and a creamy finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A dark brown stout with a dark brown head. In aroma, a smooth sweet vinous chocolate malt with coffee notes, very nice. In mouth, a smooth chocolate malt with coffee notes, grassy notes, well made. On tap at brewpub, Jan 20 2012.
This is a great big stout. Reminds me of a double chocolate chunk oatmeal cookie. I cant wait to head back there and drink this one again.

Big is an understatement! This is Black beauty! Rich Dark Brown...almost Black/Opaque pour with semi dry to curiously sweet malt character. Very Roasty with burnt edges and enjoyable flavors of chocolate, Coffee/Toffee elements. Thank you...may I have another!

Good beer. Walks an interesting line between a dry and sweet stout. The flavor profile is quite good, lots of nice bitter roast and some solid chocolate. The mouthfeel is fine, but not as rich as I would hope in a beer brewed with oatmeal. Overall, though, a very solid take on the style.
On draft at the brewpub.  For some reason I always think that I dont like this beer as much as I should and every time I try it I am a big fan.
UPDATED: JAN 15, 2015 Draft. Black. Big creamy lasting medium brown head. Nice roast. Coffee. Milk chocolate. Cocoa. Caramel. Maybe a little vanilla. Great sweetness cutting the roast.

Draft pint at the new brewery. Pours a dark coffee brown with a small beige head. Aroma of toasted malts, chocolate, mild coffee, brown sugar, oats, maple, and nuts. Flavor of milk chocolate, mild roast, sweet toasted nuts, oats, and cream. Medium-bodied, with mild carbonation and a sweet, toasty mouthfeel thats a little sticky at the end. Well done. Just to style.

Has some big bold coffee roast and chocolate scents. Taste is similar to the scent, but the roast comes out in a big way, gives it a little smokey character.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sampled at the brewpub with ck1, thanks bro! Pours a very dark, dark brown with a surprising fine carbonation. Aroma has a nice sweet semi-burnt malt smell, with chocolate, molasses and charcoal. Taste brings sweet oatmeal chocolate chip cookies, molasses and some lactose. Quite thick. Finishes dry and much quicker than I expected. Mostly sweet in the end. Rivaled Hopalicious as best at the brewery, I thought.
Slick. Slightly sweet. Nutty earthy aromas. Roast notes are low but this beer is just wonderful.
Almost black with a thick tan head. Up front chocolate & light coffee aroma. Flavor is chocolate,  sweet. Medium-heavy body,  silky, light hop bitterness.  A very well made sweet stout.

On tap @ Ale Asylum. Pour is deep brown/black with a tan head. Aroma smells like a chocolate oatmeal cookie with a touch of coffee. Flavor shows the same with nice roast and a touch of nutiness. Overall body is
moderate and creamy soft with a nicely roasted bitterness on the finish.

Enjoyed on tap as part of a sampler at Ale Asylum in Madison, WI.  Appearance a very dark black with rich off white head.  Aroma of coffee, light lactose, oats, very nice.  Taste is very good, oat comes out, light hop biiterness, also very nice.  Very good oatmeal stout!

Draft at Ale Asylum, where else. Murky black with half-finger of light brown head. Nose is roasted chocolate malts, with hints of coffee and sweet cream. Straightforward taste: more chocolate, roasted coffee, with a hint of nuttiness and smooth oatmeal texture. The thicker mouthfeel is really what sets this apart from, say, NG Road Slush. Pretty great.
6oz sample. Pitch black pour with a khaki head. Nose is sweet malts, chocolate, roasted malts, and light oat. Excellent on the palate, oat, roasted malts, chocolate, and a lightly sweet finish.

Deep, pillowy black.  Soft roast/coffee, milk, heavy cream, cocoa powder.  Clean roasted malt, cocoa, toffee, light brown sugar, lactose-esque sweetness.  Great medium+ mouthfeel from the oatmeal.  Lives up to its name of being a little slick, with great roast residual hanging on.

Draft. Pint glass poured a dark brown/black color with a nice 1 finger, thick tan head. Slightly roasty coffee aroma but otherwise not an overly strong nose. Medium mouthfeel. Dark fruit and slight roast coffee. Pretty smooth. Slight sweetness. A little booze notes in the end. Nice lace. Overall, a decent  nice drinking stout.
On tap @ Ale Asylum. Nice big roasty Oatmeal stout with lots of chocolate flavors. Thick and creamy mouth feel and very smooth. Really nice beer.
So smooooth, a big ol body stout.  Chocolate coffee mmmm delicious. (taster tap at the brewery).

On tap at the Good stout, coffee aroma.  Very dark brown coloured body with a thin head.  Rich, smooth, chocolate malts.  More coffee than chocolate. A good one for coffee fans, and even I, not a coffee regular, was fine with it. Above average mouthfeel.

Tap at the brewpub. Black pour, really frothy light cream head. Slight/moderate coffee and cream nose. Full and rich creamy mouthfeel, low carbonation, terrific. Taste is chocolate, cream, oat, and not very much roasty bitterness at all. Delicious!
On tap at Gennas Lounge in Madison, WI.  Notes only.  Creamy with a big thick head; coffee, chocolate; an odd bitter off-flavor.  One of my favorite styles, but definitely not my first choice.

Tap sample. Poured a black color with a large fizzy brown head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy dark coffee and  malt aroma. Medium to heavy dark chocolate flavor with a medium to heavy sweet coffee finish of moderate to long duration. Full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. This is a good rich beer.

Sampled on tap at the brewpub (Madison, WI). Pours an inky black pour, opaque with a frothy grey light brown head, dies to a ring and laces ok. Aromas are oatmeal, roasty barley, touches of coffee, sweet and dark chocolate, with some more roasty, creaminess, and toffee, caramel. Initial is medium bodied, maybe some bit thicker. Roasted barley, touches of coffee, a bit earthy with sweet oatmeal. Chocolate, sweet and dark. A slightly earthy finish with lingering roast and sweet toffee and oatmeal. A solid sweet stout, perhaps a little under flavored. Ok

On tap at the brewery.  A big, full bodied, oatmeal stout.  Typically one of my favorite styles and this selection was no exception.  A heady chocolate aroma is followed up by a sweet, full bodied malted taste that is tempered by the smoky notes present in the roasted malts.  It has the consistency of oil, and isnt overly carbonated.  Delicious.

Growler shared by cbfobes.  Dark black pour, average carbonation and a sweet bitter chocolate espresso aroma.  Flavor was creamy chocolate chip cookies, vanilla and a good roasty finish.  Nice surprise beer of the night, I really liked this one.
Sample at the brewpub on 10/16/10. Black pour with a thick tan head. Roasty malt nose with some sweet chocolate. Creamy chocolate flavor with a bitter roasty coffee finish.
On tap at the brewery, pours black with a weak nose and excellent flavor.  Very smooth and silky, coffee and chocolate flavors.  Good beer.

After being very impressed with the hopalicious, I was slightly disappointed with this brew...it was good but unremarkable.  Aroma slightly roasty but not terribly complex.  Not completely flat but tending towards that direction.  Although the beer was good at first, it became a little heavy upon getting to the end of the glass.  Although the alcohol content is well-masked, I wonder if this had something to do with the heavy quality of this brew.  I know this isnt supposed to be the hoppiest style, but I would have appreciated more bitterness and crispness.  A little dry, but I would have appreciated more dryness as well.  An okay beer, Id drink it again but Id try something else instead if given the choice.
On tap at brewery, very dark pour with nice tan head to it, has strong coffee and chocolate aroma with a great coffee taste, man this is good stuff from Ale Asylum!

caramel, chocolate, coffee, toast, roasty, nuts, dough, basement aromas, soy sauce, smoke, woody, black, clear, minimal head, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, oily feel, slick feel, soft carbonation,

Enjoyed out on the patio, and poured black/brown to a shaker, with thick, dark tan foam to the head, and lasting, clingy curtains of lacing. The aroma was very roasty, with coffee and cocoa notes, and a light hint of smoke/wood. Adding a complimentary amount of hop bitterness, the flavor was very similar, the body was full, the mouthfeel presented a nice, smooth creaminess, and the finish was on the dry side. Very nice as my final, dessert pint!

Very dark brown almost black, dark bakers chocolate, head depletes to a ring. Smell is coffee and chocolates, not much sweetness or malt.
Taste is fairly bitterfor an oatmeal stout with  chocolates, and roast malt flavor, oatmeal is there but not a major player.

A really enjoyable stout. Had this at the Ale Asylum brewery in Madison, WI which is a fanstastic place to have some great brews and some pretty good food. Dark color pour with nice tan head, nice lacing, smell of coffee, chocolate. Good beer!

9/05/2009:  Big Slick Oatmeal Stout...  Aroma:  Roasted malt and plent of dark chocolate.  Appearance:  Black in color with a lasting brown head.  Flavor:  Dark chocolate, slightly roasty; some mineral notes.  Palate:  Medium to medium-full body; smooth and a bit creamy.  Overall:  Balanced and quite good, but nothing overly unique.
Draught at Ale Asylum in Madison, Wisconsin.  Rating #40 for this beer.
Had on tap at the brewpub.  This is one of my favorite of their beers - a really high quality stout with great flavors and a wonderful mouthfeel.  I could drink this stuff all night!

Draft at the brewpub.  Opaque black color with a foamy off-white head.  Roasty and malty, but very smooth around the edges.  Big body, Full out thick malt.  Roasty, toasty, warm.  Pretty good, big stout.

On tap at Ale Asylum.  Dark brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma of coffee, oatmeal, light chocolate and roasted malt.  Taste of roasted malt, oatmeal, coffee and mild chocolate.  Medium mouth feel with a touch of roasted malt bitterness and moderate sweetness on the finish.  Pretty decent.
Thick, brownish head sits atop this oil-black stout. Nose is chocolate and a whiff of coffee. Flavor is roasted malt, no coffee taste though. Very solid, smooth stout.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Black oily pour with a thin beige head, dissipates to a ring.  Roast malt aroma.  Flavor is roasty, with a slightly sweet mid-palate, some chocolate and smoked meat on the end.  Smooth, full bodied, not terribly drinkable.

Draft at Ale Asylum. Pours black with a beige head. Heavy carbonation. Aroma is roasted malts, with weak hints of oatmeal and chocolate. The taste very mild, with only the slightest notes of roasted malts and chocolate. Tasted more like nothing than anything. Very watery body makes this one very drinkable without being overly good. If it was cheaper and more readily available, it could be a good get drunk and party stout. Sad to say it, but i was very dissapointed.

(Draught)  Pours a black body with a small tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, light roastiness, and nuts.  Flavor of roasted malt, coffee, caramel, and chocolate with a creamy mouthfeel and a moderately bitter finish.

GTMW 2008: Nearly opaque with a slight creamy head and some oily legs. The aroma has notes of espresso, plum and blueberry esters, oatmeal and heavy toasted malts, and a earthy yeast nose. The taste is sweet malt supported by some dark fruit and a finish that is smooth coffee. A touch of Creme Brule as well. The mouth feel is sticky and medium to full-bodied. A very nice stout.
2008 GTMW. Aroma of oats, coffee and roasted malts. Taste is much of the same and the oat silkiness is definitely noticed on the tongue. A pretty solid stout.

Pours a dark black colour, thick body, with an initially small tan head that quickly dissipates. It leaves behind little evidence of a head. Aromas of espresso beans, chocolate and burned toast. Taste is creamy, black cherry, toast and oak flavors.

Pours a nice dark brown/black color with a tan head. Great roasted malt and coffee aromas. Flavor is of roasted malts,coffee, coco and maybe a hint of caramel. Great smooth mouthfeel with anice bitter finish. Not bad! Thanks Brewblackhole!
Dark color.  Smell of roasted coffee, malt, hops, sugar and minor caramel.  Taste of malt, coffee, light caramel and coco.  Light finish and thin.  Still decent.  Thanks brewblackhole.

Warm chocolately aroma, background roasted malting,,very delicious,taste is the warm chcolate batter with a smooth roasted oatmeal finish,close to being sweet ,but not quite there,this one needs to be at perfect cellar temp to bring out all characteristics

Near black with a frothy, lightly diminished tan head. Roasted malt aromas with a backdrop of mild green hops, or perhaps green coffee. HInts of caramel and pale malts, and oats as well. Big thick rich feel. This is a stout feel for me. not sticky and lip smacking, but lush and lightly oily, with just a few tiny bubbles to keep it active in the mouth. Just looked at the ABV, much stronger than I expected. I was thinking session, but this would be a dangerous sit-down quaff. Light roasted flavors, with a little malt, a little coffee, and a touch of chocolate. Hints of licorice in the finish and linger. Dangerously drinkable.  A touch more depth in flavor and this would be killer.
Well, it is big, slick, and a stout.  Full on coffee with light cocoa and a smack of ham.  The sweet meat taste is odd, and is the sweetness gets a little cloying with the thickness.
Far and away the best of the 11 AA beers sampled at the brewpub. Black, rich, and decadent describe this oatmeal stout to a T. Silky smooth mouthfeel, roasted cocoa, some caramel. I loved it.

24oz (?) happy hour mug at the Come Back In in Madison.  Deep brown body.  Sweet, sticky rich chocolate and toasted grain flavor, with soem coffee and toffee notes, mildly sweet.  Very good, you sense that instantly, but theres something homebrewish about it.  Some plum fruit flavor, some black cherries as well, the kind of fruit notes you find in imperial stout, but here in something more medium strength.  A good stout.

On tap.   Pours a nice rich black color with a dese dark tan head.   Aroma is sweet caramel malts, chocolate, some coffee notes.   Flavor is caramel, chocolate, coffee.   Palate is full bodied, mild carbonation, finishes with a blast of roasty bitterness.   Good, but not great.

On tap at the brewpub on 6/22/07: Pours an opaque black with dark mahogany edges and a dense, frothy brown head that leaves a nice web of lace behind.  Aroma of sweet dark caramel, chocolate and roasty coffee.  Starts with a dense, fairly-full body with nice earthy sweet dark caramel and molten chocolate flavor toward a thick, lingering roasty finish.  A very nice oatmeal stout.

Date: 06/22/2007
Mode: Draft
Source: Brewpub

black, wispy tan head, lots of lace, 
big sweet roasted malt aroma, 
creamy body, 
rich dark chocolate and roasted flavor, touch of sweetness, nice oily oatmeal character, light bitterness in the finish, 

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.4/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **+/4

The other growler from Skyview for the night.  Black color with a thick head.  Very sweet malt aroma with some oats.  Toasted malt taste mixed up with chocolate and a slightly bitter roasted malt.  Well balanced and tasty, though not as sweet as Id expect.

From Skyview.  One of the better sweet stouts to be found. Aroma has toasted grain, including oatmeal, some burned popcorn.  Flavor is on the sweet side, a little sugar, and a hint of coffee.  The palate is best quality, the beer is fairly thick and very smooth.

On draught at the brewpub in Madison, Wisconsin. Pours an opqaue dark brown brew with a creamy off-white head that slowly dissolves and has good retention and lacing. Aroma of dark roasted coffee, dark berries, bittersweet chocolate and a touch of vanilla. Taste is full bodied, very light carbonation with flavors of dark chocolate, oatmeal and some roasted coffee. Finish has a mild bitterness, toasted malt with a terrific chocolate cake flavor. Quite the dessert brew.

On tap at the Ale Asylum Brew Pub. Poured a dark brown, almost black, color with an averaged sized tan head. Aromas of roast, coffee, chocolate, and lactose. Tastes of roast, coffee, vanilla, and light chocolate. Creamy body. Lacing left on the glass.
Pours deep brown and shows a classic coffee nose with the larger burnt flavors on the palate.  The oatmeal gives a nice roundness to this stout.
On tap at Angelic in Madison.  Brown foamy head,blacker than night.  That nice burnt malt taste with hints of coffee on the first couple of sips. A smooth stout for sure.   Draw me another.
This is their best beer by far, dark, bitter and smooth overall.  Some good flavor notes of light chocolate and coffee.

On tap at the Come Back Inn, downtown Madison. Dark black-brown charcoal body, thin creamy tan head. A rich stout with fair complexity, with big, sweet chocolates, roasted malts, and molasses. Nice slick mouthfeel with good heft. The kind of beer best in relatively small doses, to the tune of one to two pints.
Bold and bitter. In the style of St Ambroise and Lost Coast 8-ball, if I may be so bold. Like a restaurant with a great burger, it will hard for me to order anything else.

Draught sample at the brewery, mid-October 2006.  Opaque jet, not a sliver of light (even sunlight) coming through, small lasting creamy dark head....bitter/sweet chocolate and caramel compete with tannic dark vinous notes in the intense nose....body is just a bit too sweet, not quite one-dimensional but definitely a bit unbalanced, "slick" all right veering to syrupy....nice vanilla-chocolate nougat flavors though, and a bit of roastiness and faint woody hops do show up towards the finish.  Overall well done but needs a bit more roast and depth I think.

On tap at the Ale Asylum.  Poured a very deep brown, almost black, with a light coffee head.  Nose was rich with almost burnt milk chocolate and coffee notes.. light herbal and increasing coffee as it warmed up.  Moderate coffee and herbal bitterness throughout.. sweet and grainy.. roast worked well in there.  Rather well-balanced with a very good milk chocolatey sweetness at the finish.

Draught at the brewery tasting room. Opaque black color with tan head that laced the glass. Nice mix of aromas including chocolate, vanilla, and roasted malt. Creamy mouth feel with chocolate and coffee flavors and a lingering roastiness.

On tap at the brewpub. The body was black with a light brown and orange colored head. The aroma was pretty roasted with some coffee and chocolate. The taste wascoffee with some dark chocolate. There was also a note of cherries in this very smooth beer.
Sample @ Brewery. Had a medium sweet aroma. Black body with good tan head. Good creamy sweet flavor along with some alcohol bite. Good brew.
Pleasant light chocolate aroma with sweet, milky flavors.  Full-bodied, oily mouthfeel with lasting chocolate and coffee-ish aftertastes.  Like drinking a cookie.  Surprisingly strong.
Black body, dark tan head.  Oatmeal cookie, milk chocolate, patent malt in the aroma.  Good oily mouthfeel.  Good oatmeal + dry chocolate flavor.

Pours to a black body with a very dark brown head.  The aroma is chocolate, grass, and oatmeal.  Perhaps a little dry roasty black patent.  The flavor is a deep chocolate, grassy hops, dry charcoal.  Milken creamy and sweet mouthfeel.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2006 On tap at brewery

This was the last of the dark beers as we brought a close to the night.  As   it was one of the better beers, it made a nice nightcap before we ruined our   palates on hoppy beers.  Read on to find out why.

Aroma / Appearance  - A thin creamy head sat on top of a pitch black   body.  Hints of charcol, raspberries, coffee, roasted grains and oats all   wafted out of the tulip glass into my nose, convincing me that this was not   your ordinary brewpub stout.

Flavor / Palate  - The first impression is of a bitter expresso infused   with oatmeal and dark chocolate.  It fills the entire mouth with its wonderful   balanced taste.  Soon I also picked up some ripe black cherry textures in the   creamy mouthfeel.  It took seemingly forever for the flavors to subside from   the back of my throat; it was as if they had gotten stuck there and refused   to move on.  This was an excellently done oatmeal stout and well worth trying   if you like oatmeal infused sweet stouts.

Full aroma, loaded with dark chocolate and oats.  Nice and strong and I like it.  Dark, dark black with a light brown head that lasts.  Sweet, flavors of nutty roasted coffee, chocolate oatmeal cereal and cola.  Not much roastiness at first but it grows on you with a complex, chalky and roasty finish after time.  Medium-full body, but not super thick. Very creamy.
